moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 N: This is the well-known Sveshnikov Variation which I like to play. My overall score is not good, but I still like the complications
moves.6. Ndb5 d6: Otherwise 7. Nd6+ leads to less favorable variations
moves.7... a6 8. Na3 b5 9. Bxf6 gxf6 10. Nd5 f: After 12. Bd3, Black can play Be6
Preparing to transfer the Rook to f7, but also avoiding the fork if Black decides to play Qd7.
moves.18. Bc4 bxc3 19. Nxc3 Bxc4 20. Nxc4 Nd4: Black will end up with two passed pawns which, in the end, will decide the game.
I overlooked this move, but I sill have counterplay.
39. e2 would have decided matters, but I thought there was a mating net.
After 47. Rg4+...Kf5 and there are no more checks and the pawn queens.
